channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DERBY-1045] forupdate.sql , holdCursorIJ.sql ..etc are failing when run with 10.1 client againest trunk
item.description:
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:lang/forupdate.sql
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:lang/holdCursorIJ.sql
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:store/holdCursorJDBC30.sql
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:jdbcapi/LOBTest.java
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:jdbcapi/blobclob4BLOB.java
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:jdbcapi/parameterMapping.java
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:jdbcapi/setTransactionIsolation.java
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:jdbcapi/metadataJdbc20.java
derbynetclientmats/derbynetmats/derbynetmats.fail:jdbcapi/connectionJdbc20.java

Sample diff :

      • Start: forupdate jdk1.5.0_02 DerbyNetClient derbynetmats:derbynetmats 2006-02-23 07:30:19 ***
        23 del
        < ERROR 42X01: Syntax error: Encountered "<EOF>" at line 1, column 23.
        23a23
        > ERROR 42X01: Syntax error: Encountered "<EOF>" at line 3, column 23.
        59 del
        < ERROR (no SQLState): Invalid cursor name "C1" in the Update/Delete statement.
        59a59
        > ERROR 42X30: Cursor 'SQL_CURLH000C1' not found. Verify that autocommit is OFF.
        132 del
        < ERROR (no SQLState): Invalid cursor name "C4" in the Update/Delete statement.
        132a132
        > ERROR 42X30: Cursor 'SQL_CURLH000C1' not found. Verify that autocommit is OFF.
        135 del
        < ERROR (no SQLState): Invalid cursor name "C4" in the Update/Delete statement.
        135a135
        > ERROR 42X30: Cursor 'SQL_CURLH000C1' not found. Verify that autocommit is OFF.
        180 del
        < ERROR 42X01: Syntax error: Encountered "." at line 1, column 34.
        180a180
        > ERROR 42X01: Syntax error: Encountered "." at line 3, column 34.
        Test Failed.
      • End: forupdate jdk1.5.0_02 DerbyNetClient derbynetmats:derbynetmats 2006

item.summary: forupdate.sql , holdCursorIJ.sql ..etc are failing when run with 10.1 client againest trunk

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Diff file for the tests that failed. It includes some known failures too.

23 del
< ERROR 42X01: Syntax error: Encountered "<EOF>" at line 1, column 23.
23a23
> ERROR 42X01: Syntax error: Encountered "<EOF>" at line 3, column 23.

This diff is a result of the fix for DERBY-522. "ij" in 10.2 will trim off leading comments from a statement if the client is 10.1 or earlier, but with a 10.2 client the comments will remain in the statement.. Hence the diff in line numbers here is expected.

I don't know what the cursor diff is about.

I cannot seem to reproduce this. lang/forupdate.sql ran fine for me with:

[D:\marsden\testjars\derbytools.jar] 10.2.0.0 alpha - (380195)
[D:\marsden\testjars\derbytools.jar] 10.2.0.0 alpha - (380195)
[D:\marsden\testjars\derbynet.jar] 10.2.0.0 alpha - (380195)
[D:\marsden\testjars\derbyclient.jar] 10.1.2.3 - (380635)
[D:\marsden\testjars\derby.jar] 10.2.0.0 alpha - (380195)

and derbyTesting.jar 10.1.2.3 (380635)

1) Any idea what I might be doing wrong or how to reproduce this?
2) What revision range and checkins are at issue here on the trunk and 10.1?

I looked at my recent changes and don't think they could have this impact.
DERBY-1010 - Was a trunk client change so could not impact this testing.
DERBY-960 - Went into both 10.2 and 10.1 and only affected XA files.

Are we talking about the diff in lang/forupdate.sql which reads:

59 del
< ERROR (no SQLState): Invalid cursor name "C1" in the Update/Delete statement.
59a59
> ERROR 42X30: Cursor 'SQL_CURLH000C1' not found. Verify that autocommit is OFF.

If so, then this problem did reproduce for me.

The problem, I believe, is a combination of DERBY-213 and DERBY-821, which both involve the handling of forward-only result sets where all the rows have been exhausted.

The test does:

– . implicit update test for updatable spec
– this will end up being read only; we know because the delete is refused
get cursor c1 as 'select i, v from t1 where i is not null';
next c1;
– the delete will get a 'cursor not updatable' execution error, but won't get
– a compile time error
delete from t1 where current of c1;
close c1;

DERBY-213 (http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=264128&view=rev) changed the handling of the delete statement as follows:

delete from t1 where current of c1;
-ERROR (no SQLState): Invalid cursor name "C1" in the Update/Delete statement.
+ERROR 42X23: Cursor SQL_CURLH000C1 is not updatable.

DERBY-821 (http://svn.apache.org/viewcvs?rev=377367&view=rev) changed the handling of the delete statement as follows:

delete from t1 where current of c1;
-ERROR 42X23: Cursor SQL_CURLH000C1 is not updatable.
+ERROR 42X30: Cursor 'SQL_CURLH000C1' not found. Verify that autocommit is OFF.

It seems that the point of the test is to verify that an UPDATE on a read-only cursor is refused with a "not-updateable" error,
in which case perhaps the test needs to be enhanced, to ensure that the DERBY-821 changes don't automatically close
the table before the delete statement is issued?

Thanks Bryan for investigating this.

My understanding was that these tests started failing on Feb 22 and were passing previously, but it sounds like that is not the case.
DERBY-213 was checked in long ago and DERBY-821 on Feb 13. So I am at a loss as to what new issues have occurred and when,
but if this is the only issue with these tests then it doesn't sound like a critical issue for the release.

One thing to note about both DERBY-213 and DERBY-821 is that I think more and more, users will see errrors with the server side cursor
name which means nothing to them if they have changed it with setCursorName on client. I wonder if that should be documented or can be avoided.

You are not testing version 10.1 of the client driver, but version
10.2 against master files from the 10.1 branch.

derbytools.jar will automatically put derbyclient.jar in the
classpath. Since you have derbytools.jar from trunk before
derbyclient.jar version 10.1 in your classpath, derbyclient.jar will
be shadowed. Sysinfo will however report that you are using the 10.1
version of derbyclient.jar, since it only sees the CLASSPATH variable.

% export CLASSPATH=$derby102/derbytools.jar:$derby101/derbyclient.jar
% java org.apache.derby.tools.ij
ij version 10.2
ij> connect 'jdbc:derby://localhost/mydb;create=true;traceFile=trace.out';
ij>
% grep Driver trace.out
[derby] Driver: Apache Derby Network Client JDBC Driver 10.2.0.0 alpha - (381279)
[derby][Connection@9173ef] Driver name: Apache Derby Network Client JDBC Driver
[derby][Connection@9173ef] Driver version: 10.2.0.0 alpha
% java org.apache.derby.tools.sysinfo
------------------ Java Information ------------------

Java Vendor: Sun Microsystems Inc.

Java classpath: /export/home/kh160127/derby/trunk/jars/sane/derbytools.jar:/export/home/kh160127/derby/10.1/jars/sane/derbyclient.jar
